admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Afforestation Project for
            China achieved a highly satisfactory overall outcome. Its
            re-estimated economic and financial rates of return exceed
            those estimated at appraisal. It also has large, though
            difficult to quantify, environmental and institutional
            benefits. The project is likely to have an enduring impact
            on the development of commercial forestry, particularly the
            development of the non-state sector. The Bank's
            performance was good. It reacted positively and swiftly to
            the government's initial proposal in early 1988,
            maintained a proper focus on afforestation to the exclusion
            of complicating factors, provided continuity in staffing,
            and capitalized on the preparation of two follow-on projects
            to accelerate dissemination of research findings. The
            Borrower's performance was highly satisfactory in all
            stages of the project. Physical implementation, financial
            management, planning and monitoring, and preparation of
            documents were all rated as highly satisfactory.
            Sustainability is rated as likely, and in particular the
            plantations are virtually certain to survive and generate
            economic returns as forecasted. Six key lessons are as
            follows. First, the Borrower took ownership as the project
            was initiated by the highest level of government and enjoyed
            strong political support throughout implementation. Second,
            where institutional capacity is robust, an investment
            project can be treated as a program or sector loan. Third, a
            project with highly focused investment objectives can
            nonetheless generate a broad sectoral impact. Fourth,
            further sectoral policy reform is needed to complete the
            transition to a market economy. Fifth, the project achieved
            a high impact from research that had already been done, but
            did not address the broader constraints affecting future
            research. Sixth, the linkage of financial control with
            technical standards was critical to project success.
